Award.AwardTitle: RUI: Magmatic Evolution Leading Up to the Modern Aleutian Arc on the Alaska Peninsula
Award.AbstractNarration:
Alaska contains the largest number of active volcanoes in the United States and is one of the most volcanically active regions in the world. Most of the volcanoes in Alaska form a belt that includes the Aleutian Islands and extends landward onto the Alaska Peninsula, ending across the Cook Inlet from Anchorage. The Alaska Peninsula hosts more than 20 volcanoes with historic activity, five with major eruptions in the past 25 years, and includes the world's largest eruption of the 20th century. This project will investigate the growth of the volcanic system on the Alaska Peninsula and evaluate the factors that influence the composition and behavior of volcanoes in this region. The results of this project will contribute to ongoing work of the U.S. Geological Survey and Alaska Volcano Observatory for understanding volcanic behavior in a region where there are roughly 30,000 people per day transported in commercial aircraft over the volcanoes and where eruptions can have severe impact on Anchorage (Alaska's largest population center) and along the Kenai Peninsula. The Alaska Peninsula is also one of the nation's most important mineral resource regions; this project will provide an improved regional framework that will be useful for future detailed studies to delineate economic mineral deposits. Scientific advances made through this project will also contribute to the public-outreach mission of Lake Clark and Katmai National Parks, where several of the volcanoes of this study are located. This project will additionally provide high-level STEM training for undergraduate students. The project is highly cost-effective because it uses publically-available sample collections of the U.S. Geological Survey, building on past investments in federal funding.

Southern Alaska is one of the best places in the world to investigate long-term magmatism and crustal growth along a convergent margin, as recognized by the GeoPRISMS community who selected the Alaska/Aleutian subduction zone as the highest priority site for the Subduction Cycles and Deformation (SCD) initiative. This two-year project will benefit the GeoPRISMS community with an unprecedented synoptic study to evaluate temporal and along-strike geochemical trends for Eocene through Quaternary igneous rocks on the Alaska Peninsula. Data will include major and trace element, whole rock Nd-Sr-Hf and zircon Hf-isotopes, and 40Ar/39Ar and zircon U/Pb dating on volcanic and plutonic rocks. The results of this research will provide new constraints on the continental portion of Aleutian arc including: i) along-arc trends in magma chemistry and relationships with sediment flux and regional tectonics, ii) geochemical products of subduction over time and how these influence the composition of new continental crust, and iii) the timing of subduction initiation and relationship to Pacific-wide versus local tectonic processes. This work is in concert with the GeoPRISMS SCD initiatives to "focus on long-term margin evolution and material transfer" and "the growth and evolution of volcanic arcs and continents" and can be integrated with other projects (i.e., geophysical studies of the southern Alaska margin) to yield advances in understanding the regional controls on convergent margin magmatism.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Alaska contains the largest number of active volcanoes in the United States and is one of the most volcanically active regions in the world.  Most of the volcanoes in Alaska form an arc that extends from the Aleutian Islands eastward onto the Alaska Peninsula, ending across the Cook Inlet from Anchorage.  The Alaska Peninsula hosts more than 20 volcanoes with historic activity, five with major eruptions in the past 30 years, and includes the world's largest eruption of the 20th century.  Volcanic eruptions in this area can disrupt commercial air travel (approximately 30,000 people per day are transported by flights over Aleutian volcanoes) and can have severe impact on Anchorage (Alaska's largest population center) and the Kenai Peninsula.

The goal of this project was to evaluate the factors that influence the composition and behavior of volcanoes on the Alaska Peninsula.  This project provides the first comprehensive regional study of geochemical trends for volcanic rocks on the Alaska Peninsula, revealing west-to-east variations and extending back in time from modern volcanoes to deposits of over 45 million years ago that formed before the inception of the Aleutian arc.  Data includes whole rock major and trace element geochemistry on 181 samples with Nd-Sr isotope ratios and radiometric ages on subsets of these samples.

This work was funded as part of the National Science Foundation GeoPRISMS Subduction Cycles and Deformation initiative and contributes new data for the scientific community to meet the program goals of better understanding long-term margin evolution and material transfer and the growth and evolution of volcanic arcs and continents using the Aleutian arc as a natural laboratory.  Aleutian arc volcanoes were formed above a subduction zone in which the Pacific plate is descending (subducting) beneath southern Alaska.  As the Pacific plate descends (subducts) beneath southwestern Alaska it carries fluids and sea floor sediment.  As the descending plate heats up, the fluids are released and migrate upward into the overlying mantle causing melting and the formation of magma which rises and erupts at the surface to form the volcanoes of the Aleutian arc.  Some chemical elements tend to be more mobile in fluids and are transferred into the magma and resulting volcanic rock; these fluid-mobile elements can therefore be a marker for fluid flux (i.e., more fluid flux results in greater concentration of fluid-mobile elements).

This study involved the measurement of chemical elements in volcanic rocks on the Alaska Peninsula to test this correlation between sediment flux and fluid-mobile elements.  Results show that the concentration of fluid-mobile elements is greater in volcanoes that formed where there has been higher sediment flux in the subduction zone and decreases with lower sediment flux.  This correlation indicates that fluid-mobile elements (and thereby fluids) are released from subducted sediment along the Aleutian subduction zone.  These results confirm that fluid from subducted sea floor sediment plays a role in the formation of magmas along the length of the Aleutian arc, from the western oceanic portion to the eastern continental portion on the Alaska Peninsula.

In addition, there is a geochemical trend between older and younger volcanic rocks that indicates a change in Earth's mantle composition beneath southern Alaska about 50 million years ago, just before the earliest phase of Aleutian arc magmatism.  This trend has not previously been identified and may signal tectonic processes that coincided with the transition from intense collision and mountain building to the inception of Aleutian arc magmatism along the southern margin of Alaska.

Among the broader impacts of this research has been STEM training for undergraduate students at Allegheny College.  Undergraduate research and science education were foundations of this project which  provided opportunities for undergraduates to develop skills in scientific research design, data collection and analysis, and a diverse suite of state-of-the-art laboratory analyses.  Another broader impact of this project is that the results contribute to the regional framework of geochemical data that are important for determining the distribution of economic mineral deposits.  Finally, samples for this project were identified and selected from the U.S. Geological Survey archived collection at the Alaska Geologic Materials Center in Anchorage, Alaska.  In terms of broader impact, this project demonstrates the viability of designing regional-scale cost-effective studies that utilize existing sample collections of the U.S. Geological Survey, leveraging decades of regional mapping and sample collection, to build on past investments in Federal funding.
